story_headline: GAO: Bidenâ€™s â€˜infrastructureâ€™ bill was inefficient
story_copy: The Government Accountability Office found President Joe Bidenâ€™s so-called infrastructure bill, which passed last year, was inefficient. According to new GAO report, Democrats spent at least $65 billion with â€œno national strategyâ€ or obligation to update Americaâ€™s internet services.The reported noted, the Biden administration does not have a plan to provide high-speed internet to all Americans. The $1.2 trillion bill did not even require government agencies to develop a broadband strategy.Itâ€™s unclear how that money was spent. Republican lawmakers have said Bidenâ€™s spending spree was the main factor behind runaway inflation sweeping the US.â€œYou have to understand why demand went up everywhere, why did it go up across all segments of the economy,â€ explained GOP Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.). â€œBecause we printed money, we just passed out money. We literally passed it out this time around, but inflation is basically a consequent of debt. So in the last two years, we added $6 trillion worth of debt. Weâ€™ve never added that much debt in our history.â€New GAO report finds that the Administration has no national strategy guiding the federal governmentâ€™s spending of billions of dollars on broadband infrastructure.Thatâ€™s like turning the spigot on full blast and walking away from the hose. Taxpayers are bound to get soaked. pic.twitter.com/XRfbaNWW2Uâ€” Brendan Carr (@BrendanCarrFCC) June 10, 2022Following the GAO report, FCC Commissioner Brendan Carr called for accountability and transparency at the federal government. He asserted its spending spree has, indeed, fueled inflation.

story_headline: NATO Chief: Turkey has raised â€˜legitimateâ€™ security concerns
story_copy: NATO Chief: Turkey has raised â€˜legitimateâ€™ security concernsSwedenâ€™s Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, right, and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg attend a joint press conference at Harpsund, the country retreat of Swedish prime ministers, in Sodermanland County, Sweden, Monday, June 13, 2022. (Henrik Montgomery/TT News Agency via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:45 AM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg said Turkey has raised â€œlegitimate concernsâ€ over Finland and Sweden joining the military alliance. While speaking in Finland on Sunday, the secretary general said its important to keep in mind that no other NATO ally has suffered more terrorist attacks than Turkey.â€œThe summit in Madrid was never a deadline,â€ he stated. â€œAt the same time, I would like to see this solved as soon as possible. And therefore, we are working hard with our NATO ally, Turkey and also with Finland and Sweden to address those issues that Turkey has raised.â€Stoltenberg also claimed no other ally hosts more refugees, while noting Turkey plays a key roll in providing support to Ukraine. Terrorism and weapons exports are among Turkeyâ€™s concerns, but the two Nordic countries have agreed to continue discussions.â€œAs in international politics, it is all the reasons to take seriously what your counterpart is saying and thatâ€™s what we are going to do, take seriously what Turkey puts forward,â€ stated Sauli Niinisto, President of Finland.Good to meet President @niinisto to discuss #Finlandâ€™s application for #NATO membership. We are taking the security concerns raised by #Turkiye seriously & will remain in close contact with our Ally TÃ¼rkiye & partners Finland & #Sweden to find a common way forward. pic.twitter.com/fUq1hQCsQkâ€” Jens Stoltenberg (@jensstoltenberg) June 12, 2022Stoltenberg assured the two Nordic countries joining was the right decision and stresses it will strengthen security and stability throughout the Euro-Atlantic area.

story_headline: Rep. Ryan claims heâ€™s for â€˜working classâ€™
story_copy: Rep. Ryan claims heâ€™s for â€˜working classâ€™Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Ohio, running for an open U.S. Senate seat in Ohio, speaks to supporters after the polls closed on primary election day Tuesday, May 3, 2022, in Columbus, Ohio. (AP Photo/Jay LaPrete)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:35 AM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022Rep. Tim Ryan (D-Ohio) claimed heâ€™s for the â€œworking class,â€ even though his voting record says otherwise. In recent reports, it was revealed Ryan has actually voted 100 percent with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) on issues impacting the working class. Additionally, Ryan has reportedly voted with President Joe Biden 100 percent of the time.Meanwhile, according to reports, Ohio has itâ€™s highest gas prices in the stateâ€™s history. However, Ryan still claims heâ€™s fighting for workers in the Buckeye State.â€œâ€¦Get these jobs back, build stuff again, start making stuff again here in Ohio,â€ stated the Democrat. â€œAnd so, I want to look people in the eye. I want them to examine me, examine my record and realize that we donâ€™t need another millionaire in the Senate. We need someone who comes from a working class community.â€I want to look people in the eye. I want them to see me, see my record, and see that we don't need another millionaire in the Senate. story_headline: Economists warn inflation may still get worse
story_copy: Economists warn inflation may still get worseNEW YORK, NY â€“ APRIL 29: Mohamed El-Erian, Chief Economic Adviser of Allianz appears on a segment of â€œMornings With Mariaâ€ with Maria Bartiromo on the FOX Business Network at FOX Studios on April 29, 2016 in New York City. (Photo by Rob Kim/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:55 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022Economist Mohamed El-Erian said inflation has yet to reach itâ€™s peak. While appearing on CBSâ€™s â€œFace The Nationâ€ Sunday, the Allianz Chief Economic Advisor said he fears inflation may reach 9 percent.â€œWe got here because we got a combination of things happening,â€ said El-Erian. â€œAll these things came together and are now feeding this inflation. The price of nearly everything is going up and making us feel really insecure.â€This comes after inflation hit 8.6 percent in May, which is the highest since December of 1981. El-Erian said their was hope it would be temporary and inflation was partially avoidable, but argued the Federal Reserve mischaracterized the issue and fell behind.More US data disappointments today:Consumer sentiment, per the University of Michiganâ€™s measure, fell by 8 points â€” more than expected and to its lowest level since the index started in 1952.Also worrisome, long-term #inflation expectations rose to 3.3%, the highest since 2008â€” Mohamed A. El-Erian (@elerianm) June 10, 2022Meanwhile, during an interview with CNN Sunday, former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers disagreed with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellenâ€™s recent claims that a recession is not in the works.â€œI look at whatâ€™s happening in the stock and bond markets,â€ voiced Summers. â€œI look at where consumer sentiment is. I think their is certainly a risk of recession in the next year. I think given where weâ€™ve gotten to, itâ€™s more likely than not that weâ€™ll have a recession within the next two years.â€However, even the usual Biden critic took a jab at the GOP by claiming so-called â€œBanana Republicans,â€ who allegedly fanned the flame of the January 6 protests, are partly at fault for the nationâ€™s economic crisis.

story_headline: Bipartisan Senate group reaches deal on gun reforms
story_copy: Bipartisan Senate group reaches deal on gun reformsSen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn., speaks during a rally near Capitol Hill in Washington, Friday, June 10, 2022, urging Congress to pass gun legislation. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:30 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022The Senate group tasked with finding a bipartisan solution to gun violence reached a deal. In a joint statement on Sunday, the group, led by Senators John Cornyn (R-Texas) and Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), said their plan aimed to save lives and protect the rights of law abiding gun owners. The plan would allocate more funding for mental health services across states, school security and flags potential gun buyers who have criminal records.ğŸš¨NEWS: We have a deal. Today a bipartisan group of 20 Senators (10 D and 10 R) is announcing a breakthrough agreement on gun violence â€“ the first in 30 years â€“ that will save lives. I think youâ€™ll be surprised at the scope of our framework. 1/ Hereâ€™s what it includes:â€” Chris Murphy (@ChrisMurphyCT) June 12, 2022â€œOur plan saves lives while also protecting the constitutional rights of law abiding Americans,â€ the 20 senators said in their statement. â€œWe look forward to earning broad, bipartisan support and passing our commonsense proposal into law.â€Â Additionally, purchasers under 21-years-old will go through an investigative period to review their mental health and juvenile records. The group hopes the general Senate body will adopt their proposal.The tragedies in Uvalde and elsewhere cried out for action.Â I worked closely with my colleagues to find an agreement to protect our communities from violence while also protecting law-abiding Texansâ€™ right to bear arms.Â https://t.co/BbHGz4ydqLâ€” Senator John Cornyn (@JohnCornyn) June 12, 2022Meanwhile, President Joe Biden said he would sign the bill as is.
image_caption: Sen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn., speaks during a rally near Capitol Hill in Washington, Friday, June 10, 2022, urging Congress to pass gun legislation. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Khashoggi Wife: PGA show there are consequences for supporting Saudi Arabia
story_copy: Khashoggi Wife: PGA show there are consequences for supporting Saudi ArabiaThe 2020 Ryder CupOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:35 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022The fiancÃ© of murdered Journalist Jamal Khashoggi wants LIV golfers banned from major PGA Tour tournaments. Hatice Cengiz said the PGA should restrict golfers who join the Saudi-backed golf league.Itâ€™s alleged that its financier, Saudiâ€™s Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman, ordered the murder of her husband in 2018. She said if LIV golfers continue to play like everything is normal, they should be banned from major golf tournaments to convey their are consequences for supporting murderers.â€œIf they still carry on and play as if everything is normal, then they should be banned from playing in the worldâ€™s major tournaments,â€™â€™ said Cengiz. â€œThis will show that their are consequences for supporting murderers and it will show the murderers that they are not escaping justice.â€™â€™Commissioner Jay Monahan joined the final-round broadcast to discuss the state of golf and the PGA TOUR. pic.twitter.com/UhvtDcHiupâ€” PGA TOUR (@PGATOUR) June 12, 2022Khashoggi was a former adviser of the Saudi Government before he became one of their biggest critics. Although Saudi officials deny the allegation, US Intelligence agencies say otherwise.

story_headline: N.Y. gun owners voice opinions on gun control
story_copy: N.Y. gun owners voice opinions on gun controlNew York Attorney General Letitia James speaks during a ceremony where Gov. Kathy Hochul signed a package of bills to strengthen gun laws, Monday, June 6, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:30 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022Gun owners in New York weighed in on gun control legislation being proposed by Democrat politicians. Several firearm instructors voiced their opinion on the Supreme Courtâ€™s upcoming ruling on the stateâ€™s conceal carry law, which restricts the carrying of a handgun out in public.Today, New York joins cities across the nation to #MarchForOurLives and say:Â Enough waiting. Â Enough praying. Â Enough offering empty thoughts.Â We will fight every single day until we get the common-sense gun reforms this nation needs to end gun violence and save lives. pic.twitter.com/hD0QWItyNqâ€” NY AG James (@NewYorkStateAG) June 11, 2022Prior to this, Governor Kathy Hochul (D-N.Y.) signed several pieces of gun control legislation which raised the purchasing age for a semi-automatic rifle and expanded New Yorkâ€™s red flags.â€œIf youâ€™ve already passed a background check, hopefully youâ€™ve received some training,â€ said firearms instructor Steve Lollo. â€œIâ€™m a big believer in if you own a gun, you should be trained. If you have a permit, you should be good to go everywhere. I have a permit and Iâ€™m not shooting people here. If I carried in the city, would I be a danger to shoot people? Absolutely not. The only one Iâ€™m going to shoot is someone who needs shooting, someone whoâ€™s a threat to me or someone else. Those of us who have permits, who have gone through the process of permitting, weâ€™re the most law abiding people on the planet.â€Additionally, Second Amendment advocates voiced their disdain for the banning of high capacity magazines, which was part of an omnibus package passed by the House of Representatives in response to the mass shootings in Uvalde and Buffalo.â€œIllegal gun owners are running around with high capacity magazines,â€ voiced the instructor. â€œBut me, as a legal gun owner in the state of New York, Iâ€™m limited to ten rounds in my magazine. That person could have 30. Who would you bet on to win that fight? Some of my bullets are not going to make contact and some of his are not, but he has more of them.â€They then went on to voice their support for a solution to mass shootings being advocated for by most conservatives both at the state and federal level.â€œSchools are a soft spot for me having been a father,â€ he expressed. â€œI personally feel that if someone is going to educate my child, they should also protect my child. When it comes to teachers personal feelings are removed from it, theyâ€™ve already shown that theyâ€™re capable of higher education. Firearms are not complicated devices, theyâ€™re very simple. I personally feel you are the last line of defense with that room full of children. If youâ€™re there willing to educate them, you should be there willing to defend them with your life.â€Across the country, gun violence is wreaking havoc on our communities, and New York is not going to wait for another tragedy to step up and act.I'm proud to join New York leaders to enact nation-leading, common sense gun laws that will protect our communities. pic.twitter.com/AKbWz2wdfkâ€” NY AG James (@NewYorkStateAG) June 6, 2022In the meantime, the Supreme Court is expected to issue their ruling within the next few weeks. New York Attorney General Letitia James (D-N.Y.) will proceed with her lawsuit against the NRA in an effort to dissolve the organization.
image_caption: New York Attorney General Letitia James speaks during a ceremony where Gov. Kathy Hochul signed a package of bills to strengthen gun laws, Monday, June 6, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer)

story_headline: Marine Corps identifies 5 killed in Osprey crash in Calif.
story_copy: Marine Corps identifies 5 killed in Osprey crash in Calif.In this photo provided by U.S. Marine Corps/3rd MAW, an MV-22B Osprey with Marine Operational Test and Evaluation Squadron (VMX) 1 transports ordnance during an Expeditionary Advanced Base Operation (EABO) exercise to Old Highway 101 near Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, Calif., on May 25, 2022. (U.S. Marine Corps via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:00 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022The Marine Corps released the identities of the five Marines who were killed in an aircraft crash last week. On Friday, the officials said all victims were members of the Purple Foxes of Marine Medium Tiltrotor Squadron 364 at Camp Pendleton, California.â€œIt is with heavy hearts that we mourn the loss of five Marines from the Purple Fox family,â€ Lt. Col. John C. Miller, commanding officer of VMM-364 said in a Friday statement. â€œThis is an extremely difficult time for VMM-364 and it is hard to express the impact that this loss has had on our squadron and its families.Two pilots were killed, 31-year-old Captain Nicholas Losapio and 33-year-old Captain John Sax. The other victims were tiltrotor crew Chiefs 21-year-old Corporal Nathan Carlson, 21-year-old Corporal Seth Rasmuson and 19-year-old Lance Corporal Evan Strickland.Marine Corps Identify 5 Killed in Southern California MV-22B Crash â€” USNI Newshttps://t.co/14tliI3wJN pic.twitter.com/O7Frwd3Uz1â€” U.S. Naval Institute (@NavalInstitute) June 11, 2022â€œWe appreciate all the prayers and support from the strong extended Purple Fox family,â€ the officer voiced. â€œWe want them to know that more information will be forthcoming on how to help.â€The Osprey aircraft went down during a training exercise in the desert and the crash remains under investigation.
image_caption: In this photo provided by U.S. Marine Corps/3rd MAW, an MV-22B Osprey with Marine Operational Test and Evaluation Squadron (VMX) 1 transports ordnance during an Expeditionary Advanced Base Operation (EABO) exercise to Old Highway 101 near Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, Calif., on May 25, 2022. (U.S. Marine Corps via AP)

story_headline: Justin Bieber diagnosed with Ramsay Hunt Syndrome
story_copy: Justin Bieber diagnosed with Ramsay Hunt SyndromeFILE â€“ Justin Bieber attends The Metropolitan Museum of Artâ€™s Costume Institute benefit gala on Sept. 13, 2021, in New York. Bieber leads the iHeartRadio Music Award nominations. (Photo by Evan Agostini/Invision/AP, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:00 PM PT â€“ Sunday, June 12, 2022Justin Bieber took a break from performing after he announced he has facial paralysis. In a video posted to his Instagram Friday, the 28-year-old singer revealed heâ€™s been diagnosed with Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.According to the Mayo Clinic, it occurs when a shingles outbreak affects the facial nerve near an ear, which can cause facial paralysis and hearing loss. Biebers post came after he publicized he would be postponing a few shows.Sending lots of love, light, & prayers to you @justinbieber â¤ï¸ we love you so much! Please rest up, we are always here for you pic.twitter.com/45tiQ6HY1xâ€” Bieber Fever (@bieberfever) June 10, 2022â€œAs you can see, this eye is not blinking,â€ he said in the video, pointing to his face. â€œI canâ€™t smile on this side of my face. This nostril will not move. So thereâ€™s full paralysis on this side of my face.â€He revealed heâ€™s started having trouble eating and has asked his fans to keep him in their prayers.â€œBeen getting progressively harder to eat,â€ the singer stated. â€œWhich has been extremely frustrating, please pray for me.â€The singer said he is now going to rest and relax. He added, heâ€™s been practicing facial exercises and recovery will take some time.
image_caption: FILE â€“ Justin Bieber attends The Metropolitan Museum of Artâ€™s Costume Institute benefit gala on Sept. 13, 2021, in New York. Bieber leads the iHeartRadio Music Award nominations. (Photo by Evan Agostini/Invision/AP, File)

story_copy: $1.5M donation to Uvalde, Texas communityFILE â€“ Education Secretary Miguel Cardona speaks during the 2022 National and State Teachers of the Year event in the East Room of the White House in Washington, April 27, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:15 PM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022The Department of Education announced a major donation to the community and victims of the Uvalde, Texas school shooting. On Monday, â€œProject School Emergency Response to Violenceâ€ granted $1.5 million to the Uvalde Independent School District.This comes shortly after Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona visited the school and vowed to support recovery efforts.â€œNo community should have to experience a tragedy like this alone,â€ said Cardona. â€œWhile in Texas, I saw the Uvalde community come together in deep and meaningful ways to support one another and all the families who lost loved ones. It is our turn to support them.â€No community should be forced to shoulder a tragedy alone. Today, @USEdGov is deploying Project SERV resources to the Uvalde Consolidated Independent School District in response to the tragic events of May 24th.â€” Secretary Miguel Cardona (@SecCardona) June 13, 2022Project SERV funds are available for use under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. They can be used for activities that help restore a sense of safety and security for the districtâ€™s students, teachers, staff, and families.â€œIn the hours and days since that tragic day, we have committed to providing the Uvalde community with every available resource they may require from the Department,â€ the secretary voiced. â€œTodayâ€™s release of these emergency funds is an initial step that will be followed by technical assistance and on-the-ground supports in the months and years to come.â€According to the Department of Education, this will include funds for summer programs, new mental health services and overtime pay for teachers and staff.
image_caption: FILE â€“ Education Secretary Miguel Cardona speaks during the 2022 National and State Teachers of the Year event in the East Room of the White House in Washington, April 27, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)

story_headline: Biden: â€˜Exxon made more money than Godâ€™
story_copy: Biden: â€˜Exxon made more money than Godâ€™President Joe Biden arrives at Kirtland Air Force Base to meet with state and local officials on the New Mexico wildfires, Saturday, June 11, 2022, in Albuquerque, N.M. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:22 AM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022President Joe Biden has refused to take responsibility for astronomical gas prices, Instead, he appears to be pointing his finger at oil companies. The President accused Big Oil of exploiting supply shortages to boost profits.While addressing dockworkers at the port of Los Angeles on Friday, Biden claimed oil and gas companies are using the war in Ukraine to justify excessive price hikes. His finger pointing comes as the national average price of gas is $4.99 per gallon and is more than $5 a gallon in 19 states, according to AAA.Joe Bidenâ€™s America: â€¢40-year high inflationâ€¢Record gas pricesâ€¢Baby formula shortageâ€¢Disastrous border crisisâ€¢Crime surge Bidenâ€™s policies have failed Americans.â€” GOP (@GOP) June 13, 2022However, the President went into his typical â€œwhisper modeâ€ to deflect responsibility away from his policies that have cancelled oil field leases and restricted drilling .â€œThey have 9000 permits to drill, theyâ€™re not drilling. Why arenâ€™t they drilling?â€ Biden asked. â€œBecause they make more money not producing more oil. The price goes up, number one. And number two, the reason theyâ€™re not drilling is theyâ€™re buying back their own stock, which should be taxed, quite frankly. Buying back their own stock and making no new investments.â€Exxon spokesperson Casey Norton responded to Bidenâ€™s comments. He said the company has been in regular contact with the administration and laid out its plans to increase production as well as as expand refining capacity in the US. For starters, Norton said Exxon is significantly expanding its operations in Texas.Last month, the Biden administration cancelled three oil and gas lease sales scheduled in the Gulf of Mexico and off the coast of Alaska, removing millions of acres from possible drilling.

story_headline: Pence: Help is on the way for law enforcement at border
story_copy: Pence: Help is on the way for law enforcement at borderWASHINGTON, DC â€“ NOVEMBER 30: Former U.S. Vice President Mike Pence speaks at the National Press Club on November 30, 2021 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:35 PM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022Former Vice President Mike Pence (R) took a trip to the southern border to hear from law enforcement officials amid the Biden border crisis. On Monday, Pence spoke with the sheriff of Cochise County, Arizona and his deputies about border security.RECAP: Law enforcement and local officials reported to the 48th Vice President @Mike_Pence and AZ Department of Homeland Security Director @TimRoemerAZ that the border crisis continues to worsen. 1/ pic.twitter.com/28fB1CuOijâ€” The 9th Floor (@9thFloorAZ) June 13, 2022Pence stressed, any conversation regarding border security needs to start with officers on the front lines. However, he called out Democrat lawmakers and mainstream media news outlets that have stopped covering the crisis at the southern border.Any conversation about border security needs to start by listening to the law enforcement officers serving on the front lines. Honored to sit down with Sheriff Mark Dannels and the courageous members of the Cochise County Sheriffâ€™s Department in Arizona today. pic.twitter.com/ZRU9qeC94Pâ€” Mike Pence (@Mike_Pence) June 13, 2022â€œI truly do believe we are in the midst of an American tragedy,â€ said Pence. â€œIt is also tragic that our national media has turned their attention virtually and entirely away from the crisis at our southern border. That, as Director Roemer said, is literally costing American lives on both sides of the border.â€Pence went on to say the American people see whatâ€™s happening at the southern border and he hopes voters will elect a new generation of leaders whoâ€™ll focus on border security. This comes as critics have lambasted the Biden administrationâ€™s immigration policies, with several claiming it is causing more illegal immigration.Arizona Gov. Doug Ducey (R) tested positive for COVID-19 and wasnâ€™t able to attend the planned political event with Pence. Both are working to amplify GOP messaging on border issues that they see as a potent political issue.

story_copy: Navy announces â€˜Aviation Safetyâ€™ pauseMembers of the U.S. Navy Honor Guard pushes the casket of Navy Corpsman Maxton Soviak into Morman-Hinman-Tanner Funeral Home, Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021, in Berlin Heights, Ohio. (AP Photo/David Dermer).OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:30 PM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022The navy announced an â€œAviation Safety Pauseâ€ following a string of deadly crashes. Aviation units that have not been deployed will remain grounded, as a result of the multiple crashes in the last two weeks. The Naval Air Forces said units will review risk management practices and conduct training on threat and error management processes.â€œAs a result of recent crashes involving U.S. Navy and Marine Corps aircraft, Naval Air Forces Commander has directed all non-deployed Navy aviation units to conduct a safety pause on June 13,â€ the Naval Air Forces said in a statement. â€œIn order to review risk-management practices and conduct training on threat and error-management processes.â€As a result of recent crashes involving U.S. Navy and Marine Corps aircraft, Commander, Naval Air Forces has directed all non-deployed @USNavy aircraft to conduct a safety pause on June 13 to review practices and conduct training on threat and error-management processes.â€” Malik Earnest (@MalikEarnest) June 12, 2022A statement added, deployed units will do the same at the earliest possible opportunity.â€œIn order to maintain the readiness of our force, we must ensure the safety of our people remains one of our top priorities,â€ the statement said.This comes after five Marines were killed in a Osprey crash last week. The Marines were based at Marine Corps Air Station Camp Pendleton, California at the time of the incident.According to the Washington Post, more than 40 people have died flying on Ospreyâ€™s since 1991.

story_headline: Avenatti to plead guilty to remaining criminal charges
story_copy: Avenatti to plead guilty to remaining criminal chargesFILE â€“ Michael Avenatti speaks to members of the media after leaving federal court on Feb. 4, 2022, in New York. Incarcerated lawyer Michael Avenatti says he plans to plead guilty to charges in a federal court case in Southern California. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:21 PM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022Disgraced Attorney Michael Avenatti is set to plead guilty to remaining criminal charges against him. In a California court Sunday, Avenattiâ€™s lawyer offered to change his plea to guilty to dozens of fraud charges in connection with stealing millions of dollars from several clients. His lawyer also asked the court to schedule a hearing to formally submit the plea change.Just in: Michael Avenatti plans to take a plea in the California criminal case. pic.twitter.com/1ruajVMYqQâ€” Meghann Cuniff (@meghanncuniff) June 12, 2022â€œDespite repeated efforts over the last year by Mr. Avenatti and his counsel, including substantial efforts made in the last 30 days, defendant has been unable to reach a plea agreement with the government,â€ Avenattiâ€™s lawyer said in the Sunday filing. â€œMr. Avenatti wishes to plea in order to be accountable, avoid his former clients being further burdened, save the court, the government significant resources and save his family further embarrassment.â€Â This comes after he was sentenced to four years in prison last week, for cheating his former client Stormy Daniels out of $300,000. Avenatti is currently serving a 30 month sentence for attempting to extort over $20 million from Nike.He has asked the court to schedule a hearing to formally submit his change on the plea. His trial is scheduled to start at the end of July.

story_headline: Bipartisan gun control framework includes grants
story_copy: Bipartisan gun control framework includes grantsSen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, speaks at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on domestic terrorism, Tuesday, June 7, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:20 PM PT â€“ Monday, June 13, 2022A bipartisan group of senators announced a framework for gun control following the recent mass shootings in New York and Texas. On Sunday, the senators announced they had reached an agreement for increased mental health and school security funding, as well as expanded checks on buyers under 21.However, one provision could allow states to violate multiple constitutional rights of itâ€™s citizens. Part of the framework includes a provision to give taxpayer funded incentive grants to states, which implement so-called red flag laws.Such laws, already in place in 19 states and Washington D.C., allow neighbors, coworkers, ex-relations and family members to go to a judge and petition to have guns taken from individuals they claim are dangerous. A judge can typically order an immediate seizure of firearms, sending police to the home to remove the guns.â€œPut simply, red flag laws empower the government to take firearms first and ask questions later. Often much, much later,â€ stated Senator Ted Cruz.No crime has to have been committed, just the accusation of being â€œdangerousâ€ to yourself or others. The judge can have the separation order enforced without the citizen being present to defend themselves in court. According to the far-left ACLU, such laws can infringe not only on the Second Amendment, but also violate the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment if they are not tailored properly.A prime example of an issue that could arise from such measures occurred in Maryland back in 2018. A man had a red flag order placed against him and while no information on the reason for the order has been released, the man was not committing any crime by continuing ownership of the firearm.Despite this, police showed up to his door and he was armed, but placed the weapon on the ground until police informed him why they were there. The man reportedly became irate, picked up the firearm and had an argument with police. The argument turned violent and shots were fired, resulting in the manâ€™s death.According to Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz, this suppression of rights has no positive tradeoffs. He said research showed that red flag laws do not stop mass shootings and negligibly reduces suicides.â€œNo research has found any statistical reduction in crime,â€ said Cruz. â€œIncluding, mass shooting fatalities from confiscation laws and studies about suicide reduction show mixed results.â€Despite the red flag incentives being proposed, Texas Sen. John Cornyn, the Republican leader in the negotiations, has maintained an A-Plus rating from the NRA.Â The gun rights organization has said they will oppose efforts to strip constitutional rights from Americans, but only once a bill is drafted outside of a framework.Along with Cornyn, nine other Republican senators, including Ohioâ€™s Rob Portman and South Carolinaâ€™s Lindsay Graham, back the framework proposed red flag grants and all.
image_caption: Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, speaks at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on domestic terrorism, Tuesday, June 7, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)

Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) has claimed the Democrat-controlled January 6 Committee could come up with criminal charges against former President Donald Trump. The California Democrat alleged Sunday that he has â€œvery powerfulâ€ evidence that Trump was responsible for clashes at the US Capitol.â€œAnd weâ€™ll be presenting what weâ€™ve found,â€ Schiff told reporters. â€œI donâ€™t want to predetermine or prejudge the strength of what we will show you. Weâ€™ll show you what weâ€™ve been able to determine.â€This comes despite Trump saying he offered to deploy 20,000 National Guards ahead of the protest, but House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (R-Calif.) rejected his offer. Republicans have said Trumpâ€™s impeachment failed back in 2020 despite Schiffâ€™s similar claims of â€œpowerful evidenceâ€ at the time.â€œWell I donâ€™t think we learnt anything new,â€ said Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio). â€œI mean, we already knew that they want to get rid of the electoral college, they want to make it so that President Trump canâ€™t run in 2024â€¦I donâ€™t think we learned anything new, even with hundreds of witnesses, thousands of hours of testimony, no ability for Republicans to do any type of cross examination.â€pic.twitter.com/57aYUXneGTâ€” Rep. Jim Jordan (@Jim_Jordan) June 12, 2022Trump has also criticized the latest January 6 show trial, while asserting that itâ€™s led by a gang of â€œpolitical thugsâ€ pursuing partisan goals.
